choices.text: CT spine of the sacroiliac joint

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with complaints of chronic lower back pain, which has been progressive for the past 1 year. He also experiences early morning stiffness lasting for 1.5 hours, which is relieved by exercise. He also gives a history of anterior uveitis. Which of the following investigations is most useful for early diagnosis of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical vignette of chronic lower back pain in a young male associated with morning stiffness and a history of anterior uveitis is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis, and among the given options, MRI of the sacroiliac joint is the most useful for early diagnosis.

  • Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease classified under axial spondyloarthropathies, predominantly affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It is strongly associated with HLA-B27 and ERAP1, showing a marked familial tendency.
  • It occurs more commonly in males (ratios 2:1 to 10:1), typically presenting between ages 15 and 25.
  • The triggering factor may involve bacterial antigens cross-reacting with HLA-B27 or antigen presentation to T-cells, sometimes following genitourinary or bowel infection.
  • Pathologically, AS is characterised by synovitis of diarthrodial joints and inflammation at fibro-osseous junctions known as enthesopathy, leading to preferential involvement of tendon and ligament insertions.
  • Sacroiliac and vertebral facet joint synovitis results in cartilage destruction and reduced chest expansion. Costovertebral involvement impairs respiratory movement.
  • Disease progression follows three stages: inflammatory cell infiltration and bone erosion, granulation tissue replacement by fibrous tissue, and ossification of fibrous tissue, producing ankylosis.
  • Ossification across discs forms syndesmophytes linking vertebrae, potentially rendering the spine completely rigid.
  • Clinically, AS often begins insidiously in adolescence or early adulthood with intermittent backache and stiffness, worse in the morning and after inactivity.
  • Pain may radiate to the buttocks or thighs, and symptoms progress to continuous stiffness, fatigue, joint pain, swelling, Achilles tendon tenderness, foot strain, or intercostal pain.
  • Extraskeletal manifestations include general fatigue, weight loss, acute anterior uveitis, and, rarely, aortic valve disease, carditis, or apical pulmonary fibrosis.
  • Imaging reveals early sacroiliac joint erosion and fuzziness, progressing to periarticular sclerosis and bony ankylosis.
  • Vertebral changes include squaring, ossification of surrounding ligaments, and syndesmophyte bridging between vertebrae, producing a bamboo spine.
  • X-ray changes include squaring of the lumbar vertebrae and formation of bony bridges between the vertebral bodies known as syndesmophytes.
  • If the bridging occurs at several levels, it results in a bamboo spine as shown below.
  • MRI can detect early inflammatory changes with contrast enhancement. Laboratory findings show elevated ESR and CRP during active disease.
  • Treatment aims to maintain posture and movement, reduce pain and stiffness, and prevent deformity. It includes general posture-preserving measures, NSAIDs for symptom control, TNF inhibitors for severe disease (with IL-17 and IL-12/23 inhibitors in development), and surgery to correct deformity or restore mobility.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-CCP (Option A): Anti-CCP antibodies are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis.

CT spine of sacroiliac joint (Option C): MRI provides a detailed assessment of the sacroiliac joints and can reveal characteristic erosions and signs of inflammation, including bone oedema. Hence, MRI is considered a better investigation compared to CT in diagnosing ankylosing spondylitis.

Bone scan (Option D): Radionuclide imaging of bone is valuable for diagnosing stress or undisplaced fractures undetectable by plain X-ray, identifying small bone abscesses or osteoid osteomas, and assessing loosening or infection around prostheses. It can also detect femoral head ischaemia in Perthes' disease or adult avascular necrosis, and enables early identification of bone metastases. It has limited value in the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old female presents with chronic lower back pain. An oblique lumbar spine X-ray is done and shown below. Based on the radiological findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario of chronic lower back pain along with a scottie dog with collar sign on oblique spine x-ray is spondylolysis.

  • Spondylolysis refers to a defect in the pars interarticularis, which may be unilateral or bilateral and can be linked to spondylolisthesis.
  • Spondylolisthesis describes the forward displacement of one vertebra over the one below it, sometimes with angular deformity such as kyphosis.
  • This condition is most often seen at the L5-S1 level, less commonly at L4-L5, but may occur at other lumbar or multiple levels.
  • Spondylolysis likely develops from a stress fracture at the pars interarticularis, with repetitive extension and lateral flexion increasing shear forces.
  • Higher rates are seen in female gymnasts, football linemen, and backpack-carrying soldiers, and it is also associated with Scheuermann kyphosis. Familial clustering suggests possible genetic factors.
  • Congenital abnormalities at the lumbosacral junction, sacrum, or facet joints, as well as spina bifida occulta, may predispose to the condition.
  • Symptoms vary with age and type. Adults usually have low back pain radiating to the buttocks or thighs, sometimes with L5 radiculopathy.
  • Children more often present with gait changes, postural deformity, and hamstring tightness, which may lead to pelvic tilt, short stride length, and difficulty raising the leg when supine.
  • Imaging involves standing PA and lateral radiographs from L3 to the sacrum, with cone-down lateral and spot lateral views best showing pars defects, usually at L5-S1. L4 defects are more common in those with sacralization of L5.
  • The normal spine in oblique view shows the Scottish dog sign, and If plain films are inconclusive in spondylolysis, oblique views may reveal the classic Scotty dog sign with a broken neck or collar sign.
  • Spondylolisthesis refers to the forward slipping of one vertebral segment over the one beneath it and shows the beheaded Scottish terrier sign. (Option B ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Crush vertebral fracture (Option C): When the vertebral body is crushed in a neutral neck position, it produces a burst fracture. On plain X-ray, burst fractures appear as a crushed vertebral body, as shown below.

Klippel Feil syndrome (Option D): Klippel-Feil syndrome is a generalised disorder marked by bilateral failure of scapular descent, cervical spine anomalies, and occipital bone fusion defects, giving patients an appearance of having no neck. It is characterised by a low hairline, bilateral neck webbing, and severely restricted neck movement, and can be differentiated from bilateral sternomastoid muscle shortening by the absence of associated congenital anomalies.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a motorbike accident and is found to have a closed midshaft fracture of the left tibia. Six hours later, he develops severe leg pain that is disproportionate to the injury and worsens with passive dorsiflexion of the foot. The pain is not relieved by analgesics. On examination, dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are present, but there is no sensation over the first dorsal web space. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given scenario of development of pain disproportionate to injury not relieved by analgesics and loss of sensation is suggestive of compartment syndrome, and the most appropriate next step in management is immediate fasciotomy.

  • Compartment syndrome may occur following fractures of the arm or leg, even without major vessel injury, due to bleeding, swelling, or infection that increases pressure within an osseofascial compartment.
  • This pressure reduces capillary flow, causing muscle ischaemia, swelling, and further pressure increase, leading to necrosis of nerve and muscle within hours.
  • Muscle infarction results in permanent replacement by fibrous tissue known as Volkmann's ischaemic contracture.
  • Similar effects can result from swelling inside a tight plaster cast. High-risk injuries include fractures of the elbow, forearm bones, proximal tibia, multiple fractures of the hand or foot, crush injuries, and circumferential burns.
  • The classic ischaemia signs are pain, paraesthesia, pallor, paralysis, and pulselessness, but in compartment syndrome, pulses may remain, and skin may not be pale.
  • Severe pain, often bursting in nature, is typically the earliest and sometimes only sign. Altered sensation and weakness of active muscle contraction may also occur, requiring repeated skin sensation checks.
  • Ischaemic muscles are sensitive to stretch, so pain increases when toes or fingers are passively hyperextended.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by measuring intracompartmental pressure, with early detection being critical. Continuous pressure monitoring is advised in high-risk cases, especially in unconscious patients.
  • A split catheter is used to measure compartment pressure near the fracture, and a differential pressure (diastolic minus compartment pressure) below 30 mmHg indicates the need for immediate decompression through fasciotomy. (Option A ruled out)
  • Casts, bandages, and dressings must be fully removed, as simply splitting the plaster is completely ineffective. (Option D ruled out)
  • The limb should be kept flat, since elevating it further lowers end-capillary pressure and worsens muscle ischaemia. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male sustained a shaft of femur fracture after a road traffic accident, and internal fixation was done for the same. Two days later, he developed shortness of breath with confusion and a petechial rash. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of the development of dyspnea and petechial rash after a long bone fracture suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism.

  • Fat embolism commonly follows limb fractures, with fat globules often appearing in the blood after closed long bone fractures, and histological evidence of fat can be found in the lungs and other organs.
  • In some cases, it causes symptoms resembling ARDS, but a history of limb fractures and development of petechiae helps to differentiate between the two. (Option D ruled out)
  • The fat source is likely bone marrow, and the condition is more frequent in patients with multiple fractures.
  • Early signs within 72 hours include mild temperature and pulse elevation, progressing in some to breathlessness, mental confusion or restlessness, and in severe cases, respiratory distress and coma due to brain emboli and lung hypoxia.
  • Distinguishing signs are petechiae on the trunk, axillae, conjunctiva, and retina.
  • Diagnosis has no definitive test but may involve detecting fat globules in urine, monitoring blood PO2 (with levels below 8 kPa within 72 hours raising suspicion), and a chest X-ray for lung changes.
  • Management is supportive, with high inspired oxygen early after injury, prompt long-bone fracture stabilisation, and patient positioning in sitting to improve lung ventilation-perfusion.

Explanation of other options:

Tension pneumothorax (Option B): Tension pneumothorax occurs when a 'one-way valve' air leak develops from either the lung or the chest wall, allowing air to enter the thoracic cavity but preventing its escape. This causes the affected lung to fully collapse and compress, while shifting the mediastinum to the opposite side, reducing venous return and compressing the other lung. Common causes include penetrating chest injuries, blunt trauma with an unsealed parenchymal lung air leak, and iatrogenic damage such as from central venepuncture and mechanical positive-pressure ventilation.

Air embolism (Option C): Air can inadvertently enter the venous system through injection or be drawn into an open vein during procedures such as head and neck surgery or from penetrating trauma to the neck. It can also result from Fallopian tube insufflation or illegal abortion. When a significant volume of air reaches the right side of the heart, it can create an airlock in the pulmonary artery, leading to acute right-sided heart failure.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man undergoes routine blood work as part of a health check-up. He has no major complaints except for occasional bone pain. He denies weakness or recent fractures. On physical examination, no focal deficits are noted.
His biochemical profile is as follows:
Serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP): 710 IU/L (↑ elevated)
Serum calcium: 9.2 mg/dL (Normal)
Serum phosphate: 3.5 mg/dL (Normal)
25-hydroxy vitamin D: Normal
Parathyroid hormone (PTH): Normal
X-ray pelvis shows thickened cortices with areas of sclerosis and lysis.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given scenario of occasional bone pain with an isolated increase in ALP is suggestive of Paget's disease.

  • Paget's disease of bone is marked by localised areas of increased bone turnover, resulting in enlarged, thickened bones with abnormal internal structure and increased brittleness.
  • Pathologically, Paget's disease may involve one or multiple sites, beginning at the metaphysis of long bones and advancing toward the diaphysis, leaving altered architecture.
  • It features marked osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity, elevated plasma alkaline phosphatase, and increased collagen crosslinks (CTX).
  • Paget's disease progresses through three stages:
    • Lytic phase
    • Mixed lytic and blastic phase, where osteoblastic activity begins in response to bone resorption by osteoclasts
    • Sclerotic phase
  • The osteolytic stage shows bone resorption by large osteoclasts, replaced by vascular fibrous tissue, alongside new bone formation by osteoblasts, affecting both endosteal and periosteal surfaces.
  • This results in a thick but weak, deformable bone. As osteoclastic activity subsides, new lamellar bone fills resorption cavities, creating a mosaic pattern.
  • In the late stage, bone becomes sclerotic and brittle.
  • Clinically, PDB occurs equally in men and women, rarely before age 50, and may remain localised or widespread.
  • Common sites are the pelvis, tibia, femur, and skull. Many patients are asymptomatic, with diagnosis often incidental via X-ray or elevated alkaline phosphatase.
  • When symptomatic, it causes pain which is worse at rest or in warmth and deformities, especially in the lower limbs.
  • Skull involvement can cause enlargement, ill-fitting hats, or basilar invagination (short neck appearance).
  • Complications include cranial nerve compression (vision loss, facial palsy, deafness), otosclerosis, osteosarcoma, spinal cord compression, and spinal claudication. In some cases, it can lead to high-output cardiac failure.
  • Radiographically, the resorptive phase shows osteolysis in the form of flame-shaped lesions, as shown below, and osteoporosis circumscripta in the skull.
  • It then progresses to thick, sclerotic bone with coarse trabeculation. Stress fractures and deformity may occur, sometimes only recognised after fracture. Radionuclide scans reveal the distribution of active lesions.
  • Biochemically, calcium and phosphate are usually normal, though immobilised patients may develop hypercalcemia. Serum ALP, especially bone isoenzyme, reflects activity and extent, and helps monitor treatment.
  • Treatment with IV zoledronate effectively induces remission, often lasting years, with minimal side effects apart from transient flu-like symptoms.

Explanation of other options:

Osteomalacia (Option A): Osteomalacia is the adult counterpart of rickets, resulting from inadequate mineralisation of bone, leading to incompletely calcified osteoid that softens the skeleton, increasing fracture risk. In adults, calcium remains at the low-normal range due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, with elevated PTH and ALP, low serum phosphate, and markedly reduced 25-OHD levels (typically <10 nmol/L).

Primary hyperparathyroidism (Option B): Primary hyperparathyroidism, most often caused by a solitary adenoma, typically affects middle-aged women and may be asymptomatic or present with hypercalcaemia-related symptoms such as anorexia, abdominal pain, depression, and renal calculi. Biochemical tests reveal hypercalcaemia, hypophosphataemia, elevated serum PTH, and raised alkaline phosphatase in cases with osteitis fibrosa.

Osteoporosis (Option D): Osteoporosis is a condition marked by reduced bone mass and structural defects that make bones fragile and prone to fractures despite being normally mineralised. The cancellous bone becomes porous, and the cortices thinner, but biochemical parameters such as alkaline phosphatase, serum phosphorus, and calcium-phosphorus product remain within normal limits.
